elements that are being thought of to avoid falling in that trap and actually creating disparity rather than opportunities and a pool for so one thing that we need to clarify every time is that we are not traders so that we cannot make sure that by linking farmers to companies we our business is going to happen by itself so what we what we see is that we want to on one hand empower farmers to understand what is the value of the product they have what are the different markets they can go to and got are the benefits of working together or by developing a formal contract farming or by developing kind of loyalty to the to the potential companies that are interested in their products so that's that's a whole set of work and from the other side we work with the companies to kind of transmit they need to understand the characteristics of the farmers of the specific region where they want to source from they of course know the people but they don't they might not know how they would react to changes in the environment such as changing price scenario or changing weather scenario so this kind of of of awareness is important for the companies to have and also we have the companies to understand what are the benefits of promoting local procurement instead of imports in terms of marketing of image for for the companies and that they are seeing value in that so they are kind of open now to consider buying local Turing who sure that we know that Mexico is divided into mono cropping Jones no we have the areas about the area and so on so we want to as a part of sustainable intensification we want diversification as one of the component on the other side the contract farming is more towards specific quality trade commodity and mono cropping suits contract farming and vice versa how you see diversification and market linkage contract farming should we use only if useful so that means that not all the companies and not all farmer groups are seeing value in contract farming because contract farming is limited by stipulated programs so in that case Mexican xalapa has a circa and a circa has a service of contract agriculture which proved to be useful and unpopular in some regions and not in others so to start with this with this thing for us contract farming is not an obligation then in terms of what products we do we suggest in crop rotation we also we always start from understanding economics so whenever we see that there are several options in terms of agronomy appropriate rotation we see out of those who is the one what is the one that makes more sense from a market perspective but not the other way around we don't see we don't say ok in Bahia there is a new factory of oil of papas fritas and then we need to to get oil from this kind of legume enosis so we just understand in the system which is needed which is kind of helping to nurture soils and then out of that we we provide some recommendation I have a question especially you are talking a lot about market and specifically about big markets and slay people what about small-scale farmers if we see them yes of course also as producers and as consumers of their own cereals as maize and then if we try to connect them with you say chefs or these high like level restaurants how do we ensure that we that they can still have their own volume for self consumption and they if did we give them a nice price and all these contracts yeah of course it's gonna be a really nice incentive to sell everything on most of it and then what are they gonna eat if they prefer to eat their own mace perhaps we are going to make a different type of impact yeah well I think that was that was pointed out by I mean we do that by carefully assessing case by case first we cannot say that large farmers supply only large companies so that is the large companies also supply from small and medium farmers that get organized that's what we are doing in Bahia that's where we are doing in in some in Sinaloa not so much but in estado de mexico yes we're doing that for those niche market pool for that niche market pool that they want maybe some very specific products land resumes we have been doing this exercise community by community in Venezuela Yucatan to understand what is the percentage of product that they consume what is the percentage of product that they trade in their communities so we don't affect that we help them to increase their production and with that surplus of production we start talking about selling that so the volumes are incredibly low for the first year then we want to help them to make to see okay maybe they have three actors of land in average they are planting less than an actor because it's what they need but maybe next year they will think okay I'm gonna duplicate my production because I know I will have who someone who's going to buy from from me so volume setting and price setting is key and it's something that we work on in every specific community this is very time demanding so what we would want to do is that we have the private sector I mean small companies farm advisors dispatcher salary colas that provide a service to
